story:
Science-ing: /'sīɘns-iNG/ verb., the teach-ing, experiment-ing, explore-ing, discover-ing, hands on do-ing of science.  Science as the active pursuit of knowledge, not just passive memorization of science-facts.  Like a super hero action ... Not just a verb... but a super verb!

Why Contribute to the LXS?

The League of Extraordinary Scientists and Engineers is a 501c3 non-profit. Our mission is to do our part to help San Diego educators teach young students to be THINKERS, CREATORS, INVENTORS and the next generation of MAKERS.

LXS provides hands-on "science-ing" to Pre-K to 5th grade learners by contributing in-classroom support for their educators -- FREE to all schools and libraries. 

It takes a community to EXPLORE, DISCOVER and ENGINEER a new generation of Critical Thinkers. Our talented team of Local Science, Technology & Engineering  Professionals have developed in-classroom tours that are constantly evolving (as all good science does).  LXS brings these passionate scientists and engineers right to front of your classrooms to provide exciting, hands-on exploration and discovery experiences. 

Sharing our knowledge not only assists educators to meet new and evolving standards, but also EXCITES KIDS' basic INSTINCT to DISCOVER and LEARN and, most importantly, to THINK.

We are very excited to have you join us!

Our Impact

Last year, LXS had over 15,000 student contacts through our unique classroom tours.  Our current budget constraints have required us to cap our 2014-2015 scheduled student contacts at 22,000.  We will be visiting over 30 schools, several public libraries, and many before- and after-school programs across San Diego County. LXS is gearing up to meet other science and engineering communities throughout our nation to provide valuable insight on organizing and being part of the essential community effort to support Science in K-5th grade.

Our Community Needs Your Support

LXS is a 501c3 non-profit organization. The League of Extraordinary Scientists & Engineers program is available throughout San Diego County. 

We have $96,000 in yearly expenditures. To date, our operating budget is provided entirely by personal and community donations.  

With support from Local Community Leaders, collaborations with other STEM education non-profits and generous Grants, LXS can fulfill its commitment to visit over 1,250 classrooms during the 2015/2016 school year.   

The LXS larger goal is to be fully funded for the next four years so we can provide a stable, FREE resource to all K-5th grade classrooms while educators and schools work towards meeting new and evolving standards. 

Your contribution will support our ability to continue to give K-5 classrooms in San Diego County equal access to our hands-on, interactive science education tours. We bring a unique community of specialists that is ready and willing to do its part in lifting San Diego County students in the specific area of "science-ing".

Our Programs

The local science and engineering community has come together to create unique, hands-on, engaging STEM tours that go right into K-5th grade classrooms. With our forever-growing Advisory Board, LXS keeps up-to-date with the latest scientific information and exciting discoveries.

Most K-5th grade educators are not STEM professionals. Passionate teachers are constantly seeking tools and resources to help give their students the best possible education available. After every class, LXS gives the in-class educator a tool for evaluation and feedback and we strive to work with teachers in order to be of the most valuable use of classroom time. The gathered data from evaluations has clearly shown an overwhelming TEACHER APPROVAL of 4.8 out of 5. 

Our scientists, engineers, graduate students and STEM/STEaM-loving parents and other volunteers teach their passion right next to the in-class educators. Every tour is designed to ENCOURAGE all KIDS to EXPLORE, DISCOVER, SHARE and THINK like a scientist.

ESTIVATION, HIBERNATION, MIGRATION

Where do all the snails go in the summer?  How do different animals survive and thrive? Counting heartbeats: What is the difference between sleeping in and hibernating? 

We explore our own heartbeats and examine the difference from true hibernators. Otis, our desert tortoise, and a few others will be in attendance on this tour.  This tour is in schools mid-September - October and then we come back to the classroom for a brief visit in March after Otis wakes up so students can weigh him again to compare with his pre-hibernation weight. 


This tour is perfect for Pre K-1st grade learners.
Estimated Student Contacts: 3,750

MAKING WAVES

Did you know that when we take three deep breaths, the oxygen for two of those breaths comes from plants that live in the ocean?  How do plants work?  Why aren't all plants green?  What is a holdfast? 

Marine plants may provide our atmosphere and help reduce global warming, but we actually know so little about them!  In the "Making Waves" tour, students are introduced to marine plants and are encouraged to think critically about what makes a plant a plant. We will discover what makes marine plants different from land plants, how we use products from marine plants every single day (think toothpaste and ice cream!), and how students become investigative marine biologists on their next beach day.  This tour will help develop skills in critical thinking and hypothesis formation and will introduce students to the global carbon and oxygen cycles. 

This tour is perfect for 4-5th grade learners. 

Estimated Student Contacts: 6,240

INSIDE OUT

Did you know that flies taste with their feet? What is the strongest KNOWN animal on the planet per its body weight?  Where do we classify a vinegaroon? Are bugs gross or given more data-possibly the anti-gross?

Often thought of as the "BUG TOUR!" This tour explores the very foundation of the "how" we as SCIENTISTS gather and SHARE discoveries GLOBALLY. A Dichotomous or "Sorting" Key is very much like our own dresser drawers at home…We put items in different drawers so we can easily find them. Introducing Biological Classification, this tour brings to life an EXCITEMENT for EXPLORING, DISCOVERING, OBSERVING and ultimately drawing/WRITNG & REPORTING.  We also demonstrate how scientists all over the world share information and learn more about OUR PLANET as GLOBAL COMMUNITY.

This tour is perfect for 3rd-4th grade learners. 

Estimated Student Contacts: 6,250

LIFE CYCLES

Did you know YOU are "VIVA" VIVIPAROUS? You start off your life cycle ready to eat, drink and breathe oxygen!

We bring tadpoles, frogs, beetles, mantis, and more! During this tour, we teach how everything alive has a life cycle and we talk about how those life cycles are all interconnected - Seeds to Plants, Babies to Adults, Eggs to Butterflies. We also learn about how scientists explore, discover, journal and share information to better understand our planet. We observe differences in life cycles to compare and contrast including, for example, the difference between chrysalis and cocoons. We bring live OVIPAROUS butterfly eggs to view on the LCD screen microscope and determine what kind of caterpillar is inside based on the clue of what kind of leaf it is on. LXS allows all of its students to come up close, be hands-on, and explore.

This tour is perfect for 1st-3rd grade learners. 

Estimated Student Contacts: 7,750

IF YOU PLANT IT - THEY WILL COME

After asking thousands of kids to explore and discover, we have found that so many students neither have the easy access nor the time outside of school to really explore. Working with Butterfly Farms, Luca Nursery, the U.S. Air Force Silver Wings Volunteers, and gardeners in and around San Diego, LXS organizes and fundraises to build gardens that grow the specific plants that pollinators look for. Students watch all school year as these gardens bring forth new life cycles. LXS comes back to the gardens to teach the "Ambassadors" of these gardens to maintain and educate other students during before and after school programs at each school.

Our Student Ambassador Program encourages older students to care for these gardens while exploring and discovering with younger students during before and after school programs in each school.

Estimated Student Contacts in our Ambassador Program: 2,250

Science-ing Nights at San Diego Public Libraries

Get your whole family excited about "science-ing"! We wanted to extend our access to kids and families over the summer months, and the San Diego Public Library provides a perfect place to beat the heat and become excited to explore. This has also become a resource for homeschool communities and after school science programs. 

This tour is perfect for Pre K to 5th grade learners

Estimated Student Contacts: 3,080

SD KIDS EXPLORED & DISCOVERED


LXS Kids from all over San Diego County send in the journal entries they have created of anything with a life cycle that they have found and observed in and around the county! These entries be a part of our giant LXS dichotomous "sorting" key. We would like the key to be hung on display in the Downtown San Diego Library as early as August 2015, but we need more SCIENCE JOURNALS to give our students! 

LXS Origins

The League of Extraordinary Scientists & Engineers began in 2009. It was clear, after a few years of bringing bugs and other life science to before-school and after-school programs, that basic critical thinking was being over-looked in the very (early) years it is most easily absorbed. In July 2013, LXS's founder, Jeane Wong, gathered together an amazing group of San Diego minds to address this issue head on.

We entered K-5th classrooms as LXS in September 2013 and had over 15,000 student contacts by the end of our first school year. This number was far greater than our 4,500 target. The demand was both amazing and telling. It became absolutely clear by January 2014 that K-5 classrooms were desperately seeking hands-on science activities.

We quickly realized that many other science outreach programs charge schools and libraries, forcing many schools to choose between critical field trips or in-class hands-on science experiences. We adopted our by-laws in a deliberate effort to give equal access to all K-5th classrooms -- LXS will always be FREE to all schools and libraries. 

LXS is an incredible community effort to enhance, introduce and engage "science-ing" for San Diego County K-5. We have already touched the lives of tens of thousands of students, and we've only just gotten started. Your support will help us reach tens of thousands more.

PERKS

$25 Sponsorship
The League of Extraordinary Scientists & Engineers Journal and Pen gets you ready to explore- discover and collect data. 



$100 Sponsorship

iBoost-Exec Mobile Charger with Gift Box: Provides a battery boost for mobile devices without an external power source. Rechargeable - Connect to wall outlet or car charger after use to repower. Powers mobile phones, tablets, MP3 players, GPS devices, and more!. Charges as quickly as 5 hours. 2200mAh Lithium Ion battery. Peak output of 1000mA. Awesome Gift with order of 50 or more chargers. 3 3/4" W x 13/16" H

$300 Sponsorship
BUGS & BURRITOS W/Jeane (Perfect for 4-11 year old)

This Summer, Jeane will come to your home and pick up your kid up for a day long adventure. 8am PICK UP @ your home! We will Bug Hunt, Explore, & Discover ! POWER BREAKFAST @ Local fruit stand.We will EXPLORE@Wild Animal Park & Discover @ Butterfly Farms -BIG BURRITOS WILL BE HAD!

The Winner of this auction will receive 

1. Exhausted, dirty child full of memories & pictures throughout our day sent to you!

IF YOU KNOW JEANE, SOMETHING ELSE at 5pm drop off at your home. 




$500 Sponsorship
A behind the scenes tour of Scripps Institute Of Oceanography

Including tours through: *climatology *marine biology *underwater vehicle development *research aquarium: Tours will include a walk through the marine biology research aquarium and out on the Scripps pier, and depending on interest levels, can include visits to the Nimits marine facility, Birch Aquarium, Venter Institute and deep sea marine vertebrate collection (over 1.5 million preserved specimens).  Includes lunch and 4 Birch Aquarium tickets.

The sponsor of this PERK will be given contact information for Jeff McQuaid to schedule the best day to experience this one-of-a-kind, unforgettable day!


Journal Sponsorships

LXS needs Science Journals to give to more than 22,000 K-5th grade student contacts for our fiscal year 2015/2016. For about $0.09 -$0.24 cents per journal, your LOGO will be printed on every single journal. These journals go right into the hands and backpacks or K-5th Grade San Diego County Kids. You can sponsor one or more spaces on these journals to show your support of science in education across San Diego. Your LOGO along with a personal Thank You will also go on our Website and FaceBook Page. Our Front cover Journal Sponsors will also have LOGO recognition on all of our 2015/2016 brochures that are distributed to local & international Scientists and Engineers, Educators, Community Local State and National Leaders and parents throughout our county. 


Notes: LXS Science Journals are planned to be 8.5" x 5.5" journals that children can keep. Creative on journals will be subject to change. Sponsors are subject to board approval. If you have any questions, please contact Jeane Wong for more details.

Science-ing: /'sīɘns-iNG/ verb., the teach-ing, experiment-ing, explore-ing, discover-ing, hands on do-ing of science.  Science as the active pursuit of knowledge, not just passive memorization of science-facts.  Like a super hero action ... Not just a verb... but a super verb!

Why Contribute to the LXS?The League of Extraordinary Scientists and Engineers is a 501c3 non-profit.  Our mission is to do our part to help San Diego educators 
teach young students to be THINKERS, CREATORS, INVENTORS and the next generation of
MAKERS.

LXS provides hands-on "science-ing" to Pre-K to 5th grade learners by contributing in-classroom support for their educators -- FREE to all schools and libraries. 


It takes a community to EXPLORE, DISCOVER and ENGINEER a new generation
of Critical Thinkers. Our talented team of Local Science, Technology & Engineering  Professionals have developed in-classroom tours that are constantly evolving (as all good science does).  LXS brings these passionate scientists and engineers right to front of your classrooms to provide exciting, hands-on exploration and discovery experiences. 

Sharing our knowledge not only assists educators to meet new and evolving standards, but also EXCITES KIDS' basic INSTINCT to DISCOVER and LEARN and, most importantly, to THINK.
We are very excited to have you join us!

Our Impact
Last year, LXS had over 15,000 student contacts through our unique classroom
tours.  Our current budget constraints have required us to cap our
2014-2015 scheduled student contacts at 22,000.  We will be visiting over 30 schools, several
public libraries, and many before- and after-school programs across San Diego County. LXS is gearing up to meet other science and engineering communities throughout our nation to provide valuable insight on organizing and being part of the essential community effort to support Science in K-5th grade.

Our Community Needs Your Support
LXS is a 501c3 non-profit organization.  The League of Extraordinary Scientists & Engineers program is available throughout San Diego County. 
We have $96,000 in yearly expenditures. To date, our operating budget is provided entirely by personal and community donations.  
With support from Local Community Leaders, collaborations with other STEM education non-profits and generous Grants, LXS can fulfill its commitment to visit over 1,250 classrooms during the 2015/2016 school year.   
The LXS larger goal is to be fully funded for the next four years so we can provide a stable, FREE resource to all K-5th grade classrooms while educators and schools work towards meeting new and evolving standards. 
Your contribution will support our ability to continue to give K-5 classrooms in San Diego County equal access to our hands-on, interactive science education tours. We bring a unique community of specialists that is ready and willing to do its part in lifting San Diego County students in the specific area of "science-ing".

Our Programs


The local science and engineering community has come together
to create unique, hands-on, engaging STEM tours that go right into K-5th grade classrooms. With our forever-growing Advisory Board, LXS keeps up-to-date with the latest
scientific information and exciting discoveries.
Most
K-5th grade educators are not STEM professionals. Passionate
teachers are constantly seeking tools and resources to help give their students the best
possible education available. After every class, LXS gives the
in-class educator a tool for evaluation and feedback and we strive to work with teachers
in order to be of the most valuable use of classroom time. The gathered data
from evaluations has clearly shown an overwhelming
TEACHER APPROVAL of 4.8 out of 5. 
Our
scientists, engineers, graduate students and STEM/STEaM-loving parents and other volunteers teach their passion right next to the in-class educators. Every
tour is designed to ENCOURAGE all KIDS to EXPLORE, DISCOVER, SHARE and THINK
like a scientist.

story:
Short Summary

Contributors funds will be used to expand the number of Scholarships for low income students. The funds will let more students, parents, and teachers know about how eTAP can increase student success worldwide. Please see our many Success Stories.

  • In the USA there are about 30 million students who need help in our Elementary and High Schools. About 30% of our students drop out of High School. The use of www.etap.org  at an alternative High School, increased the pass rate from 30% to 86% on the High School Exit Exam. Please see our Test Prep.
  •  As a nonprofit, eTAP provides free use to students below the poverty level.

eTAP's personalized learning is designed for students with English as a second language and those with different learning styles. Please see our User Guide.

What We Need & What You Get

  • The $75,000 will be used to increase the number of Scholarships we can provide to low income students by letting more students know about eTAP learning program.
  • All those who contribute will receive free use of the website www.etap.org. A contribution of $50 will receive 3 months free use, $99 - 6 month use, $200- 12 month use, $500- 3 yr, and $1, 000 -10 yr use.
  • If we do not reach full goal the funds will go to other ways of letting people know about the benefits of using eTAP. If we receive more than our request funds will be used to expand the purchase of media time and upgrade the instructional content.

The Impact

We have invested millions in creating www.etap.org and testing its effectiveness for helping students. Now we need your help in letting the world know about eTAP. In addition to schools and students in the USA, we have received interest in using eTAP from Ministries of Education in Trinidad, Jamaica, Nigeria and Kuwait. Your contribution will allow us to succeed in expanding the number of students we can help. Please see our many Success Stories.

Risks & Challenges

The only education programs that have succeeded are those where the amount of money spent on creation is equal to the amount spent on marketing. We have invested the funds on creation and now need your contribution to invest in marketing. 

With your help, all students will know the secret of learning success with eTAP. The $75,000 would provide funds to market eTAP worldwide and to help all students succeed at an affordable cost and provide free scholarship use to low income students.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us by telling your friends about our free trial, posting information about eTAP on Facebook, Blogs and use Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Our first round of fundraising raised $5,856! Thank you to everyone who donated. But, we still have a ways to go. With your donation we can continue connecting the communities and cultures of Asheville and Ivory Coast for generations to come. 

A Rich Resource Lost

Adama Dembele is a 33rd generation musician from Ivory Coast, West Africa, who resides in Asheville, NC. On January 12, 2015, the Ivory Coast government demolished his family home and many others in Abobo (a city of 1.5 million people), citing erosion and unsafe conditions, a fact that is common in this part of the country where very little infrastructure exists. Thousands of people were pushed out of their homes with one week’s notice—some forced at gunpoint—and were given no temporary housing or compensation. Many families and children are now homeless, and there is little expectation that the Ivory Cost government will provide housing or reimbursement for those impacted. Financial assistance is needed. 

The Asheville Connection

Also impacted by this atrocity was the Djembeso Drum & Dance Education Center, a place for people of all ages to study drumming, dance, and learn about West African culture. Local Asheville musicians have traveled to study there, including members of Zansa and Toubab Krewe, as well as countless others from around the world. The Dembele household, known as Djembeso, or House of Djembe, has been a link between Asheville and West Africa for over a decade, though his family has been sharing their music here for centuries. The fact that Adama is a 33rd generation musician means that his family has been passing on their musical heritage and culture for nearly 700 years. Adama has been sharing that heritage with the Asheville community in many ways; teaching through LEAF Schools & Streets, performing, and hosting drum workshops locally and throughout the United States. Currently, the family is unable to continue passing on this wealth of cultural knowledge. 


Help Make A Difference

The Dembele family can’t rely on the Ivory Coast government to rebuild their home and music center and are relying on support from Adama’s Asheville community and beyond. Please consider making a monetary contribution to help his family rebuild. Thanks to support from LEAF Community Arts, your donation is tax deductible.


What Is Needed

We raised almost $6,000 in our first round of funding. If we raise another $15,000 we can start building! We've got plans in the works for our new building, which we will share with you as soon as possible. 

Here are our needs:

$15,000 to purchase land

$19,000 to rebuild the Dembele home and Djembeso music center

$6,000 for Adama’s travel expenses to and from Ivory Coast



Risks & Challenges

As with most of West Africa, Ivory Coast faces many challenges, such as poor infrastructure, access to clean water, and political strife. But, with Adama's language skills (he speaks English, French, Bambara, and Baoule) and his personal and professional connections in Ivory Coast, he and everyone behind this campaign can meet this challenge. If we don't raise all of the money needed, we will still be able to buy a plot of land and start the building process. Any amount will help.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute, you can still help! Please spread the word about this campaign; emails, sharing on social media, and even word of mouth all go a long way.

Local Asheville musicians have traveled to study there, including members of Zansa and Toubab Krewe, as well as countless others from around the world. The Dembele household, known as Djembeso, or House of Djembe, has been a link between Asheville and West Africa for over a decade, though his family has been sharing their music here for centuries. The fact that Adama is a 33rd generation musician means that his family has been passing on their musical heritage and culture for nearly 700 years. Adama has been sharing that heritage with the Asheville community in many ways; teaching through LEAF Schools & Streets, performing, and hosting drum workshops locally and throughout the United States. Currently, the family is unable to continue passing on this wealth of cultural knowledge. Help Make A DifferenceThe Dembele family can’t rely on the Ivory Coast government to rebuild their home and music center and are relying on support from Adama’s Asheville community and beyond. Please consider making a monetary contribution to help his family rebuild. Thanks to support from LEAF Community Arts, your donation is tax deductible.What Is NeededWe raised almost $6,000 in our first round of funding. If we raise another $15,000 we can start building! We've got plans in the works for our new building, which we will share with you as soon as possible. Here are our needs:$15,000 to purchase land$19,000 to rebuild the Dembele home and Djembeso music center$6,000 for Adama’s travel expenses to and from Ivory CoastRisks & ChallengesAs with most of West Africa, Ivory Coast faces many challenges, such as poor infrastructure, access to clean water, and political strife. But, with Adama's language skills (he speaks English, French, Bambara, and Baoule) and his personal and professional connections in Ivory Coast, he and everyone behind this campaign can meet this challenge. If we don't raise all of the money needed, we will still be able to buy a plot of land and start the building process. Any amount will help.Other Ways You Can HelpIf you are unable to contribute, you can still help! Please spread the word about this campaign; emails, sharing on social media, and even word of mouth all go a long way.

story:
Who are we?  

We're Afrique-co, a project created by a group of students of the European Campus of Sciences Po Paris in Dijon. Every year, our project organizes an international solidarity mission to an African country. 
This year, we've concluded a partnership with SOSVOL-TOGO, a Togolese youth association that promotes development, education and intercutural exchange. Alongside SOSVOL, we're organizing a month-long volunteering trip to the village of Wonougba in Togo. This year, four of our members will be departing during the summer. 

Our project is based in three main activities:                                                               
  • A program of academic support in Wonougba's school. We will work closely with teachers to help them manage their classes and to give an extra support to students who need it. Additional tutoring programs will be held every afternoon. On top of that, we will organize cultural and artistic activities, as well as sports for the children of the village. 
  • A Europe-Africa cultural exchange program. Since our group of volunteers is composed of diverse nationalities (Slovakia, Czech Republic, Norway, Italy and Venezuela), we have planned the organization of a European day in order to present our countries and our traditions. There will also be a Togolese day so the villagers of Wonougba can share their traditions with us. Moreover, we will be living full time with a group of five Togolese volunteers, who will collaborate and guide us in the mission. 
  • A small-scale construction project. During the weekends, we will dedicate ourselves to help SOSVOL in the construction of straw roofs for the local market.

What will we need?

We calculated a budget of 5000 Euros for 4 volunteers. This budget includes:

  • Accommodation and food expenses 
  • Air tickets
  • Visas
  • Administrative fees
  • Vaccinations and medicines
  •  Material for activities 

What will be the impact of our project? 

Photo taken by our former members in a mission to Kounoune, Senegal. 
Our project will mainly benefit the local community of Wonougba, especially the children who will benefit from extra tutorials to help them advance and learn, and from leisure activities.
The inhabitants of the village will also benefit since we will help to build roofs of straw for their local market, and we're willing to help SOSVOL with anything they need in terms of construction. 
 We also consider that the intercultural exchange we're organizing is one of the  strong points of our program. We really hope that this exchange between Wonougba's community, the Togolese volunteers and us will be an opportunity for all of us to learn, get rid of prejudices that might exist and to encourage intercultural tolerance.  
Can't help? Don't worry, there are other ways to help us!

Spread the word, give us some advices, share your experiences, follow our blog http://afrique.co ...

A big thank you from the members of Afrique-co!

Version française 

Qui sommes-nous? 


Nous sommes Afrique-co, un projet crée par un groupe d'étudiants du Campus Européen de Sciences Po à Dijon. Chaque année, notre projet organise une mission de solidarité internationale dans un pays Africain. 

Cette année nous avons conclu un partenariat avec l'organisation Togolaise SOSVOL-TOGO, une association de jeunesse Togolaise qui promeut le développement, l'éducation et l'échange interculturel. Avec l'aide de SOSVOL, nous organisons une mission de bénévolat d'un mois au village de Wonougba, où quatre de nos membres se rendront cet été.


Notre projet est basé en trois activités principales:

  • Un programme de soutien scolaire dans l'école de la communauté. Nous coopérerons avec les enseignants locaux pour les aider à gérer les classes et pour donner un soutien supplémentaire aux élèves qui en ont besoin. Des tutorats d'après-midi seront aussi mis en place pour aider les étudiants dans les matières fondamentales. En dernier lieu, des activités socio-culturelles, sportives et artistiques seront mises en place pour les enfants du village.

  • Un programme d'échange culturel Europe-Afrique entre nous et les populations locales. Vu que notre groupe est composé par des personnes de différentes nationalités (Slovaque, Tchèque, Norvégienne, Italienne et Vénézuélienne), nous avons planifié l'organisation d'une journée Européenne pour pouvoir présenter nos pays et nos traditions. Il y aura aussi une journée Togolaise pour que les villageois de Wonougba partagent leurs traditions avec nous. En plus, nous habiterons avec cinq bénévoles Togolais qui nous aideront dans la mission. 

  • Un projet de petite construction:Pendant les weekends, nous comptons nous engager dans des tâches de construction, notamment dans la construction de toits en paille pour le marché local, vu que les infrastructures du village restent précaires. 

    • Notre budget:

    Nous avons prévu un budget de 5000 Euros pour couvrir les dépenses des 4 participants, ce budget consiste en: 

    • Les dépenses de logement
    • L'hébergement
    • Les frais administratifs
    • Billets d'avion
    • Visas
    • Vaccinations et médicaments
    • Le matériel pour les activités en classe

    Quel sera l'impact de notre projet? 

    Photo prise par un de nos anciens membres dans une mission à Kounoune, Sénégal. 

    Notre projet profitera à titre principal à la communauté locale de Wounougba, et d'une manière spéciale aux enfants, qui bénéficieront de tutorats de soutien scolaire additionnels pour les aider à progresser et à apprendre, ainsi que des activités ludiques pour leur détente. 

    Les habitants du village pourront aussi bénéficier du projet vu que nous allons aider à construire des toits en paille pour leur marché local, et nous tenons à aider SOSVOL avec tous ce dont ils ont besoin en matière de construction. 

    Nous considérons que l'échange interculturel que nous organisons est un des points forts de notre programme. Nous espérons vraiment que cet échange entre la communauté de Wonougba, les volontaires Togolais et nous seront une opportunité pour tous d'apprendre, de se débarrasser des préjudices qu'on pourrait avoir et d'encourager la tolérance interculturelle. 

    Vous ne pouvez pas nous aider? Ne vous en faites pas, il y a d'autres façons de nous aider!

    Passez le mot, donnez-nous des conseils, partagez vos expériences, suivez notre blog (http://afriqueco.com)...

    Un grand merci de la part de tous les membres d'Afrique-co!

story:
A Briefing on South African Deaf Rugby:

In South Africa, our community is supporting our national team as much as possible with products and services.
From tog bags, banners, the use of fields and referees and medical staff, specific training routines and programs - all for the support of our nation Deaf rugby team.

It takes a little more than a smile to get 40 men to one venue, to cater for them and make sure all the costs are covered to make a professional and good experience for all.

The money raised will be focused on supporting and preparing our men for the Wales tour in August 2015, as well as make the Welsh feel comfortable and enjoy their African experience.

The South African Deaf Rugby Union is committed to globally growing Deaf rugby, the very game echoes in the blood of every South African.
We as a nation, as a union, are committed to enhancing the Deaf community as a whole, to support Deaf initiatives and create confidence in the minds of employers all over South Africa to see deaf and hard of hearing persons as productive employees.

Contributors to Deaf rugby will not only being helping the Deaf community all over Southern Africa - they will be helping thousands of men achieve their dreams through the great game of rugby.
We have a powerful team on and off the field, sticking together; from Strength to Strength.

You can deposit directly to our attorneys if you prefer:

Cordiers Attorneys

Absa Bank(RSA)

Acc: 4072980109

Branch code: 632005

Ref: Deaf Rugby
SWIFT Code: ABSAZAJJ

Why Deaf Rugby?

The funding will be directed at the South African national squad - in what ever they require to make them successful in their 2016 world cup bid.

As contributors, you will a part of this journey, a part of this history in the making; you will be a part of helping people believe in themselves again, deeply, through sport and teamwork.
If you would like your name to be a part of our brand - as a contributor - depending on the amount, you will form part of our advertising role - even if you would like to put your contribution in a family name for generations to come to know your family helped make history in the Deaf rugby world.

    The Impact

    With this campaign, we wish to unite people globally for awareness of Deaf rugby as a whole - South Africa is a rugby nation and we feel strongly that through our rugby efforts - we will be able to make the dreams of thousands come true.
    And thats the greatest impact we could ask for, to help others achieve their dreams, from Africa to Asia, Australia to America - we unite as one, through sport.

    Risks & Challenges

    No risks, biggest challenge we have is to collect funds to make sure our men and woman are taken care of in terms of medical care if needed, gum guards, boots and many other small items which make the massive difference in their lives.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Refer to our Facebook pages - https://www.facebook.com/groups/SouthAfricanDeafRugby/

    &

    https://www.facebook.com/SADeafRugby

    @SADeafRugby

    Talk to friends and family about Deaf rugby, spread the word, keep their dreams alive...

story:
"Education is the most powerful weapon to change the world"

Nelson Mandela


Who am I? My dream is  to create a better future for the most vulnerable children from the Linda Blind Farm in Zambia.

I am Xavier Friesen. I’m 12 years old and I live in the Netherlands.  I’m in the seventh grade. My mission became to help the most vulnerable children in Zambia so they can build a better future!

A year ago I had that plan to go on a study trip. When I looked to see manners to do volunteer work my eye felt to a Dutch Travel Agency with a beautiful project in Zambia, Africa. Zambia is nowadays a pour country. In particular outside the big cities.

This project is called The Linda Blind Farm School. There was this school for children from the pre-school.  All very vulnerable children with very pour, mostly disabled parents.  And this is what I saw: the schoolbuilding was terrible!  80 children in a schoolbuilding from 4 by 4 meters. With 3 classrooms in it.  I did not believe my own eyes. 3 classrooms in 4 by 4 meters! That is a little more than my toilet at home! And 80 children in that building!

My heart immediately was stolen by this children. Was my first plan to be a teacher for 5 weeks here, I was convinced their needs had to be something very different. I decided to do fundraising for a new schoolbuilding. So I designed a campaigne to raise money for this new schoolbuilding. I came on national televison, in the national newspaper for children and thousands of people read my blog. I made a website, organised with friends a sponsor-tour etcetera etcetera. And the money came in.

The first time in Zambia!

When it was February 2014, I had raised up more than 21.000 euros for the new schoolbuilding! So I I went, for the first time, 5 weeks to Zambia.

In Zambia I had the time of my life. The children were very happy me teaching them.  At that time two teachers were in charge.  I found two Zambian organisations to work together with me to make the dream of a new school come true. Of course the teachers and people of the Linda Blind Farm were very much involved. I talked to a architect to build the most beautiful school of Zambia and negotiated about a drawing, the costlist and so more. Ii went to the gouverment for support and I talked to the mayor about the school. I wrote the president a letter. Of course I also travelled in Zambia for three days (a safari) but mostly I was busy making plans for the school with my partners in Zambia and teaching the children.

The schoolbuilding was really so small and there were really 80 children. At times everyone came to school this number reached up to 100. What me impressed the most was the pleasure and happiness on the faces from the children. They really love going to go school. The children came every day very happy to school in spite they don’t have a lunch or had to walk a long time on almost bare feet (and it was rainy season at that time). If they were lucky they had popcorn as lunch.

When I went back home the arrangements were made and the builders began to build the school.

The second time! The opening.

In July 2014 I went back to the Linda Blind Farm. A dream came true: the school was almost finished en I went back to open the school. It was so nice to see the children again and to share with them the happiness of the opening ceremony. I gave a speech for two hunderd people and counselers. It was a experience I will never. This was a very important step to help these vulnerable children to build a better future!


Also at that time I organized a schoolcomite. In my last week in Zambia there was the first meeting of this school comite. It was a very special meeting. We discussed a lot about important matters. We made a lot of arrangements. For example: I think this is the first school with a maximum of children in one class. 30 children. The schoolcomite decided about this because of the quality standards they want to achieve for the children. So they asked for  the solutions in Holland. And after discussion they made this very important decision.  . We have an amazing school.


What do the children need?

But the dream had a second part.  There is still one big problem. My aim was also to take care the children did not have to have their schooleducation on the floor. This problem was the lack of schoolfurniture. In the old school there was no space to sit.  All the children and teachers had to stand on their feet during schooltime. Their schoolwork they had to do holding the papers on the wall and write down their exercises. There was no money left to buy enough furniture for all the children.

What is the need of the furniture? Not only for the children and teachers in the current pre-school. But there is a second goal  to expand the school. The aim of the schoolcomite, the partners and my foundation is to expand the use of the school up to 200 vulnerable children in 2017. We want to extend this school with the primary school. So the access to education is guaranteed also when children finish their preschool and continu their education in the primary school. Now we have only 70 children. In 2017 we want to have all the primairy classes in our schoolbuilding. 200 children can build a better future at that time. But 10 till 15/16 years children and young adults, need chairs.

So we need furniture for all this children. Once I returned in Holland I began to collect schoolfurniture. Now I have collected over 100 tables, chairs and other furniture and supplies. I have raised an other 5500 euros to pay the transport to Zambia. But it cost more than 9500 euros. This children need 4500 euros more to have a seat so they can build a better future.

Now I see you questioning why I ask for help on this crowdfunding project in Amerika. There is a reason for this.  As a student at my primary school in the Netherlands now I am allowed to do a special project. They allow me to spend a few hours a week at a special project. And therefore I choose to work on for my dream and the dream for this children! My challenge in this project is to see the best way to raise the money needed for this vulnerable children. On the 18 of June 2015  I have to present this project to a lot of people in the Netherlands. An hour before I closed this special crowdfundraising project. And my dream is that at that very moment I raised the money to help those children with a chair, a table and all the other necessary schoolneeds. All the money more than 4500 euros goes also to the Linda Blind Farm school but on other ways, for example to train the teachers.

For more info check: www.bouwstenen-zambia.nl, (Bricks for Zambia) . With google translate you can translate it  into the Englisch language.

On this website I write my blogs.  Also you can like my page on facebook so you can read this blog also.

When you have questions? Please, ask me. This is the emailadres of my project. xavier@bouwstenen-zambia.nl

Please, help this children to build their better future. Because a real school really does help!

Thank you,

Xavier Friesen.

build a better future!




Also at
that time I organized a schoolcomite. In my last week in Zambia there was the
first meeting of this school comite. It was a very special meeting. We
discussed a lot about important matters. We made a lot of arrangements. For
example: I think this is the first school with a maximum of children in one
class. 30 children. The schoolcomite decided about this because of the quality
standards they want to achieve for the children. So they asked for  the solutions in Holland. And after
discussion they made this very important decision.  . We have an amazing school. 



What do the children need?
But the
dream had a second part.  There is still
one big problem. My aim was also to take care the children did not have to have
their schooleducation on the floor. This problem was the lack of schoolfurniture. In the old school
there was no space to sit.  All the
children and teachers had to stand on their feet during schooltime. Their
schoolwork they had to do holding the papers on the wall and write down their
exercises. There was no money left to
buy enough furniture for all the children. 

What is the
need of the furniture? Not only for the children and teachers in the current
pre-school. But there is a second goal 
to expand the school. The aim of the schoolcomite, the partners and my
foundation is to expand the use of the school up to 200 vulnerable children in
2017. We want to extend this school with the primary school. So the access to
education is guaranteed also when children finish their preschool and continu
their education in the primary school. Now we have only 70 children. In 2017 we
want to have all the primairy classes in our schoolbuilding. 200 children can
build a better future at that time. But 10 till 15/16 years children and young
adults, need chairs.
So we need
furniture for all this children. Once I returned in Holland I began to collect
schoolfurniture. Now I have collected over 100 tables, chairs and other
furniture and supplies. I have raised an
other 5500 euros to pay the transport to Zambia. But it cost more than 9500
euros. This children need 4500 euros more to have a seat so they can build a
better future.
Now I see
you questioning why I ask for help on this crowdfunding project in Amerika. There
is a reason for this.  As a student at my
primary school in the Netherlands now I am allowed to do a special project.
They allow me to spend a few hours a week at a special project. And therefore I
choose to work on for my dream and the dream for this children! My challenge in this project is to see the
best way to raise the money needed for this vulnerable children. On the 18 of
June 2015  I have to present this project
to a lot of people in the Netherlands. An hour before I closed this special
crowdfundraising project. And my dream
is that at that very moment I raised the money to help those children with a
chair, a table and all the other necessary schoolneeds. All the money more than 4500 euros goes also to
the Linda Blind Farm school but on other ways, for example to train the
teachers.
For more
info check: www.bouwstenen-zambia.nl, (Bricks for Zambia) . With google
translate you can translate it  into the
Englisch language.
On this
website I write my blogs.  Also you can
like my page on facebook so you can read this blog also.
When you
have questions? Please, ask me. This is the emailadres of my project. xavier@bouwstenen-zambia.nl 
Please,
help this children to build their better future. Because a real school really
does help!
Thank you,
Xavier
Friesen.

story:
Catalyst for Change

Together with your support, 14 youth volunteers from Youth Corps Singapore aspire to transform the way children in Cambodia learn English. We are working closely with Young Men’s Christian Association (YMCA) in Singapore. We will be introducing technology into the educational curriculum in Boys Brigade Learning Center (BBLC) in Siem Reap, Cambodia.

Our initiative allows students to 

- leverage on technology and improve their command of English language 

- gives students technological knowledge to pursue better-paying jobs when they graduate

- encourage independent learning outside school curriculum time 

The village has minimal exposure to technology. With your help, we will bring in tablets and enhance their learning capabilities.


Resources Needed

Your generous donations will be used to subsidize the project implementation cost including the purchase of

- unwanted but fully functional tablets

- wireless routers

- earpieces 

- storage stations to ensure that the tablets will be securely stored 

These tablets and technological resources will be donated to BBLC. Full time staff from YMCA will be based in BBLC to ensure that our technologically based english curriculum is implemented as planned, even after we leave. This paves the path for sustainable change.


Impacting lives beyond borders

'The best time to plant a tree was 20 years ago. The second best time is now'. 

Children in Siem Reap have always been dependent on traditional methods of learning, such as using chalk and paper. We know the power of technology. We wish that those in Cambodia could harness technology and seize these opportunities. With the endless possibilities that technology can bring, it is never too late to introduce technology to them. 

Why Cambodia?

According to the Unesco National Education Support Strategy Report (2010), 

- An average Cambodian primary school has 1 teacher to 50 students.

- High student to teacher ratio means that each student receive less attention, making the learning process a challenging one for most students. Independent learning is impossible due to limited resources. With tablets, students can learn at their own time.

- Only 12.4% of the government's expenditure is spent on education.

- 32% of the population survives on less than a dollar a day. Parents are unable to self-fund their children's education.

By integrating technology into the BBLC's educational curriculum, we can nurture the young minds and empower them to become successful people in society. it serves as a starting point for children to explore other methods of learning. These children can access the usage of educational apps on the tablets on their own and improve their command of English language. Together we increase their literacy rates, we open up opportunities for them to seize better paying jobs, we elevate them out of poverty. Technology will change their lives!


Other Ways You can Contribute

Singaporeans only: We are also looking for secondhand tablets which are fully-functioning. If you have a tablet and are willing to donate, please email us at ycs.marshall@gmail.com. We will love to arrange a meet up to pick up the tablet from you. Collection will stop on 26th April 2015. 


*It will be helpful on our logistics if tablets reach us by 26th April 2015

story:
THE NEED

Armenia is a landlocked country with limited economic growth opportunities. Lack of infrastructure contributes to high level of poverty.  Especially, the rural areas are isolated and underprivileged lacking regular access to economic markets, healthcare and educational opportunities.

During the last decade unprecedented increase in Internet usage across Armenia — 0.1% to nearly 50% — has placed the country among the top Internet users in post-Soviet countries. Mobile and wireless devices have driven this accessibility and growth — 62% of households own a personal computer and 28% access the Internet via a mobile device.

New technologies present a vast array of opportunities for Armenia’s further development.

WHO WE ARE AND WHAT DO

We are a team of young Armenian professionals passionate about education and the possibilities of new media technologies. We strongly believe that the technological advances can greatly contribute to developing a thoughtful, educated, and confident young generation of professionals in Armenia. That’s why we created the eLearning, cloud-based portal of Dasaran (which means ‘classroom’ in Armenian) as a vehicle to help realize our vision for a 21st century education for Armenia’s new generation.

Since its inception in 2009 Dasaran has grown into a large-scale feasible project and a unique online education network connecting all schools across Armenia: providing a common workspace for communication, co-learning, co-creation and school management for all stakeholders in the pedagogy system—students, teachers, parents and local authorities.

In 2009, the introduction of e-tools (e-Gradebook and e-Planner) into Armenia’s school management network system was pioneered to help raise transparency in the school systems and provide effective monitoring for all parties involved in the education process.

Following this, our pilot project developed into a virtual communication platform that connected school age students across Armenia allowing for social interaction, sharing and a gamified content that turned learning into a fun, entertaining and more effective experience. A special online reward scheme—points and badges— was created to recognize and share the achievements of every student within their circle of classmates, thus encouraging healthy competition to improve school performance.

After six years of dedicated, volunteer hard work, we proudly serve a user community of 925,383, which includes: 437,706 students, 437,706 parents/guardians, and 49,911 teachers in 1,495 schools across Armenia and Artsakh. Through generous support of our private donors, we have continued to provide Dasaran’s opportunities free of charge to all the participants.  

We have successfully bridged the learning and technology divide across Armenia’s most remote regions making education a common endeavor and accessible to every school and household.

OUR STRETCH GOAL of $250,000 USD

To continue our free services for all our current students and schools, we need to raise $250,000. This will allow us to provide students, parents and teachers with free, innovative learning, peer-to-peer instruction opportunities, collaborative environment and monitoring tools.

To ensure the availability of these tools and opportunities for our target audience and to continue to provide updated learning modules, content, and new online features, every school requires a monthly fee of $14 or $168 per academic year.

Your contribution of $170 will sustain one school out of 1,495 served, for one year and multiply our success stories across Armenia and beyond.

Take action! Adopt a school!


PROJECTS YOUR DONATIONS CAN HELP FUND

We hope to introduce the following new features/tools on Dasaran platform once we reach our fundraising target:

Teachers’ Co-Working Space

A virtual space where teachers across Armenia and Artsakh can share professional achievements, offer and receive support from colleagues and share various educational and schooling issues of concern.

Parents’ Room

Enable all parents connected to the network to communicate with their peers and share concerns on different education-related topics. This will ensure their active involvement in their child’s education process and help organize community actions to end status quo and bring change.

D-Numbers

Using big data analytics tools we can compile detailed statistics about each student’s performance, growth potential and the challenges they face. This will help us provide forecasts to parents, as well as students, about their potential educational endeavors.

D-Cultural Hub

The Cultural Hub will help connect Armenia’s schools to more than 130 museums, galleries and art centers in Armenia and promote museum visits as an ideal family activity. By offering unique and customized programs for schools we hope to increase their knowledge base about Armenia’s cultural heritage as well as world art and culture.

THE PATH TO SUSTAINABILITY

The core of Dasaran is a social innovation aimed to reach out to the most vulnerable groups in the Armenian society by expanding horizons for growth. However, the sustainability of the platform is a challenge we hope to achieve in the future.

We have adopted various features to assure Dasaran’s sustainable and healthy growth:

  • Introduce fee-based premium features for parents and teachers users
  • Provide potential partners with an opportunity (workspace) to share their education-related content with our users
  • Provide interested collaborators with space and expertise for developing eLearning curriculum
  • Connect Armenian Diaspora schools with schools in Armenia - with a fee
  • Create Dasaran Club, a circle of paid subscribers (members/friends) sharing common values, enthusiastic about eLearning and eager to share expertise to further enhance this project
  • Attract and collaborate with international donors to implement joint, large-scale educational projects

OTHER OPPORTUNITIES FOR ENGAGING WITH DASARAN

You can also support Dasaran by:

  • Spreading the word about this campaign by using Indiegogo sharing tools.
  • Share your eLearning expertise with us

Contact our team to find other ways you can help.

WE VALUE YOUR CONTRIBUTION! TAKE ACTION BEFORE YOU LEAVE THIS PAGE!

story:
THE SHORT STORY

If the sex education taught in schools is teaching our youth to be silent and uninformed about sex, we are teaching non-consensuality to our youth.

#FUNDCONSENT aims to raise money to teach consent-based sex education workshops to teenaged youth, with no cost to their hosting school or organization. The initial $5,000 goal will fund a semester-long series of consent-based sex education workshops at Lighthouse Holyoke, a newly-established, self-directed learning center for teens in Holyoke, Massachusetts. If more money than the $5,000 goal is raised, consent-based sex education workshops will be offered to other interested, local high schools and youth organizations which will be tailor-made to their specific, sex educational needs.

Low on the Dough? Other Ways You Can Contribute:

  • SHARE this IndieGoGo Campaign with both your personal and social media networks.

  • Use the HASHTAG #fundconsent to bring attention to the Campaign on Instagram & Twitter.

  • Follow #fundconsent’s social media journey on Facebook/y.tallonhicks, Instagram @the_vspot & Twitter @the_valleyvspot.

  • DONATE workshop materials such as paper, markers, and safer-sex supplies (trusted distributors only). Email y.tallonhicks@gmail.com to request the entire wishlist.

  • Send KIND WORDS of encouragement to y.tallonhicks@gmail.com. Free, simple, yet go a long way.



THE FULL STORY

We are really bad at talking about sex. Our lacking school-based sex education, which mandates the stressing of abstinence in over half our U.S. states, paired with our cultural knack for social stigmatization has made sure of it. As women are taught to be sexually receptive, passive, and submissive, or, to “Just take it”, men are being socialized to sexually take charge, to “know everything”, to be emotionally detached, or, to “Just fake it”.

These socially-prescribed, gendered sexual roles puts everyone in an often non-consensual and terribly misinformed place with sex. Socially and formally, we are teaching both youth and adults to keep their mouths shut when it comes to sex, with our very masculinity or femininity at stake.


Modern sex education - learned through media, peers and government-funded school-based sex education - is teaching youth to be silent about sex unless the word spoken is simply  “NO”.


However, young people are saying yes to sex. 73% of adolescents are having sex by the age of 19 and about one in seven teens have had sex before their 15th birthday. This gap between youth’s lived experience and the sex education available to them shuts down any opportunity youth have to engage in a dialogue about the role of sex in their real lives with the information they need to make consensual choices for themselves and with their partners. And the impact of this matters:

  • Approximately 8 in 10 teen girls and 1 in 3 teen boys who had sex at age 14 or younger report that they either didn’t really want to have sex at the time, or had mixed feelings about having sex at the time.

  • A majority (53%) of millennials say that high schools are not doing enough to address the issue of sexual assault.

  • Women between the ages of 16 and 24 are 4x more likely to be raped than women in other age groups.

  • Approximately 1 in 8 lesbian women and nearly half of bisexual women experience rape in their lifetime.

  • Nearly half of bisexual men and 4 in 10 gay men have experienced sexual violence in their lifetime.

  • A staggering 64% of transgender people have experienced sexual assault in their lifetime.

  • Researchers found that among 12 to 25 year olds in the Netherlands, where sexuality education begins in primary school and includes topics such a sexual diversity & sexual assertiveness training, most say they had  “wanted and fun” first sexual experiences.

  • In contrast, 66 percent of sexually active American teens surveyed said they wished that they had waited longer to have sex for the first time.

Four in ten millennials say that school sex education classes were not helpful to them in making decisions about sex and relationships.


73% are having sex. But is it consensual?

Consent is about arriving at and saying an enthusiastic yes. Consensual sex is sexual activity that occurs with informed, enthusiastic agreement between each partner involved. Consent is an active, ongoing process that can be revoked or revised at any time. Consent can only be achieved via conversation and communication, by asking for permission and being granted that permission verbally.

Consent is spoken. Consent is informed. Consent is verbal.


If the sex education taught in schools is teaching our youth to be silent and uninformed about sex, we are teaching non-consensuality to our youth.


If we are denying our youth accurate information about sex, we are teaching them to make misinformed decisions about sex.

When we teach youth to never ask questions about themselves or others in regards to sex, we are teaching them to “just take it” and to “just fake it”. Consent-based sex education can break this cycle.

#FUNDCONSENT aims to raise money to teach consent-based sex education workshops to teenaged youth, with no cost to their hosting school or organization. Our initial $5,000 goal will fund a semester-long series of consent-based sex education workshops at Lighthouse Holyoke, a newly-established, self-directed learning center for teens in Holyoke, Massachusetts. If more money than the goal is raised, consent-based sex education workshops will be offered to other interested, local high schools and youth organizations which will be tailor-made to their specific, sex educational needs.


What is Consent-Based Sex Education?

Consent-based sex education understands that sex is about so much more than inserting a Tab A into a Tab B. Consent-based sex education believes that sex is about relating, negotiating, and setting boundaries; that sex is about emotions, identities, self-care and sexuality; and that sex is about so much more than just sex. Therefore, our sex education should be about more than just the risks of or abstaining from sex.


Consent-based sex education believes youth are entitled to the accurate and honest information they need to make safe and healthy decisions about themselves, their sexual identities, and their sexual and romantic experiences. And that consensual skills will make a lifelong positive impact.

(At a consent for youth workshop I taught earlier this year, a youth participant shows off her 'consent cookie' made during our sugary activity that helps bring to life consent strategies learned earlier in the workshop)


The goal of every consent-based sex education workshop is to meet youth where they’re at in their lives and relationships in an approachable & appropriate setting to help them break down the linguistic, mental & emotional barriers standing in the way of creating a culture of consensual communication at their schools, in their peer groups and for their future sexual explorations.


This integrative approach to youth sex education isn’t new and boasts some of the world’s best outcomes when it comes to teen sexual health, happiness and behavior. 


Yet this type of sex education is simply not funded by the U.S. government nor is it taught in our traditional schools. As a self-directed learning center, Lighthouse Holyoke is in a unique position to offer this (optional) type of sex & sexuality education to their teens. As an independently-funded non-profit, Lighthouse Holyoke is also enthusiastic and grateful for self-funded educators offering their services to their students.


Who Am I?

My name is Yana Tallon-Hicks and I am a sex & sexuality writer and educator living in Northampton, MA. My work centers around the belief that pleasure-positive & consent-based sex education can positively impact our lives and the world.

After receiving my undergraduate degree in a self-designed major of LGBTQ, youth education & sexuality studies from Hampshire College in 2008, I was trained by Dr. Carol Queen & Dr. Charlie Glickman in sexuality education in San Francisco, CA. I’ve been writing & educating about sex and sexuality, for both youth and adults, ever since. In 2017, I will be awarded my Masters Degree in Marriage & Family Therapy from Antioch University in the pursuit of becoming a practicing sex therapist in the Pioneer Valley.

I have years of experience working with teenaged youth in leadership positions, having worked as both the co-director for Rowe Center’s Senior High Camp & the Youth Director for the Unitarian Society of Northampton & Florence.


I believe that young people who are empowered with accurate information about, and receive trusted adult support around, their own experiences will make positive choices for themselves and others in their own lives.


My workshops for youth and adults work to create a welcoming & comfortable space to explore and learn about crucial aspects of our holistic, sexual selves, using humor, normalization & relateability as primary teaching tools. My workshops for youth are tailored to be approachable & age-appropriate and focus on essential components of healthy sexuality and relationships for young people including consent, communication, safer sex & body-ownership.

You can find out more about me on my website, YanaTallonHicks.com.


Where Does Your Donation Go?

Besides scoring you some awesome, consent-promoting, sex-positive perks (consent postcards! consent patches! safer sex kits! books!), your donation goes towards…

  • workshop materials, including take-home materials for youth such as basic safer-sex supplies & continued education materials like information packets & books.

  • work-hours devoted to developing & teaching these workshops to youth.


I am a self-employed sex educator & writer and make a modest living teaching what I know, what I love & what is making a difference. My typical workshop fees cover materials, advertising, workshop development, and teaching time, with little left over for my living expenses. I teach many workshops pro-bono throughout the year. 

Your donations make it possible for youth organizations like Lighthouse Holyoke and others to hire me to teach these workshops, a fee that is often uncoverable by grants & specified budget-lines.


Crowdfunding makes it possible for youth to engage with progressive, consent-based sex education that is unavailable to them via traditional government funding & schooling.


Low on the Dough? Other Ways You Can Contribute:

  • SHARE this IndieGoGo Campaign with both your personal and social media networks.

  • Use the HASHTAG #fundconsent to bring attention to the Campaign on Instagram & Twitter.

  • Follow #fundconsent’s social media journey on Facebook/y.tallonhicks, Instagram @the_vspot & Twitter @the_valleyvspot.

  • DONATE workshop materials such as paper, markers, and safer-sex supplies (trusted distributors only). Email y.tallonhicks@gmail.com to request the entire wishlist.

  • Send KIND WORDS of encouragement to y.tallonhicks@gmail.com. Free, simple, yet go a long way.


Thank you for reading. Thank you for sharing. Thank you for funding better sex education for youth.


GRATITUDE TO THOSE WHO DONATED PERKS TO #FUNDCONSENT

Beautiful postcard art/design by Sarah Jane Young (sarahjaneyoung7@gmail.com).

Keep it Consensual logo design by Patrick MacDonald.

Keep it Consensual & Canines for Consent patches by babegangpatches.

SEX: A book for teens: An uncensored guide to your body, sex, and safety by Nikol Hasler.

Good Clean Love organic cinnamon-vanilla lubricant.
